section.name: Localizing Gforge
section.p:
Gforge has been engineered to allow internationalization; the user interface can be viewed and translated in any language.
The language files are located in the www/include/languages directory.

section.name: Adding a new language
section.p:
These are the steps to add a new language:
add a row in the supported_languages table in the gforge database:
INSERT INTO SUPPORTED_LANGUAGES (language_id, name, filename, classname, language_code) VALUES (NEXTVAL('"supported_langu_language_id_seq"'::text), 'German (Austria)', 'Austrian.class', 'Austrian', 'AT');
Note that the language_code should follow the international language codings.
Copy the file Base.tab to Austrian.tab and place it in the www/languages/include folder
Translate the document
Submit the translation to the gforge project

section.name: How to localize an existing application
section.p:
To localize an existing application, all hard-coded strings in the application must be removed with the corrisponding getText() calls.
Follow the steps:
Open Base.tab and add a new entry to the file.
The base translation file has, for each line, 3 arguments: module name, locale_label locale_string. You should use a unique name for your module (e.g. forum, tracker, etc), a name for your label (e.g. Title) and the string. E.g. for the title of the forum, you should insert: forum\t title\t Discussion Forums .
Replace the text in the source code with the call $HTML->getText('forum','title')
